threads.com:
Go /p/ro:
• Please post images that are JPG format and ideally smaller than 1 MB, and/or about 1000 pixels on the longest side.
• Expect to be judged harshly. Learn to deal with it.

Want:
• We come here for photos, so post yours as often as possible, even if "image unrelated" to your text.
• "Flickr/500px/Tumblr/Facebook/Portfolio" threads are for critique and networking.
• Use "Recent Photos" threads if you are shy or only want to post a couple of photos.
• Shared raw files which we can collectively edit for discussion of post-processing techniques, are encouraged.
• Use the Catalog to consolidate similar topics (photographic themes, images or technical gear threads).

Do not want:
• Go to /wsr/ or /r/ for specific Photoshop requests.
• Gear threads are discouraged, but identified as necessary. Many users simply hide these threads.

Want to learn more?
• The /p/ Wiki

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>4106223
Under bright sunlight it's easy to frame with a viewfinder.
OP mentioned film cameras, he will have a smoother transition if he gets used to a viewfinder.
You can stabilize the camera better holding it against your eye.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>4106232
I would add that it generally easier to manually focus with a viewfinder than a with a rear screen. This is applicable for reflex and EVF designs. Some cheap point and shoots have an optical viewfinder. These aren't useful for focusing or displaying information but are good for framing, steadying the camera, general practice ect.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>4106280
>are good for framing
With a zoom lens? lol hard pass

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>4106286
I take that back, just looked at the specsheet and the viewfinder itself zooms in and out

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>4106286
>>4106290
Just because a feature isn't absolutely perfectly useful with with one specific use case you have contrived doesn't mean its 100% worthless you impulsive savage. In this instance sadly it needs to be pointed out to you that:

Zoom lenses zoom towards a center point.
The camera can be zoomed in using the rear screen to initially frame.
Then the user can switch to the the viewfinder for the shot as all they need to do is point towards the center of the area they zoomed in to.
Being able to shoot in this manner will certainly provide a steadier shooting method than just holding the camera out in front like a retard, zooming and hoping for the best keeping it steady when the shot is taken.
This method becomes indispensable when the object being photographed is moving, as aiming from directly at the eye and moving your head will always produce better results than simply holding the camera out in front at arms length and swinging it wildly.

The only beginner mistakes that could be made in this scenario are over zooming too tight so as not to have a little leeway and simply not knowing anything about the camera or where is targets. All it takes is a little practice ffs.

I guess it also needs to be pointed out to you that there are an infinite number of picture taking scenarios that can occur. Clearly an optical viewfinder will be of advantage in a good many of them. So even if not always ideal it doesn't make the feature worthless. If given the choice of a point and shoot with or without an optical viewfinder included the obvious choice for anyone serious about taking pictures will be for the one that has one regardless of how crude it is.

threads.com: I want a digishit. Any meme worthy digishits yet that I shoud be bulk buying and keeping on ice.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>4105895
No because digishits are already overpriced. Everything old has already been flushed out and goes for market value now. Just hit up second hand stores. Of you see something look it on fleabay. If you thinks its a good deal to flip then buy it. Keep in mind retro digi buyers aren't aren't interested in junk. They want mint condition cameras in full working order preferably with accessories, add on lenses, ect. No one gives a shit about the original boxes, manuals, ect. Its all garbage that just has to be stored. Keep in mind not all old cameras are worth money. Most are are worth $10-20. Some are worth more but only if they are complete all original and in mint condition. The most important thing to remember is most old digital cameras really have very little value. There are thousands of old cameras on the market. Some of them sell but most don't because because greedy fucks are asking way too much. Don't look at fleabay asking prices. Look sold for prices. Often times there will be dozens of some old camera model for sale with sellers asking $100-200 or more. Go and check sale prices and there will be a few dozen that have sold for less than $50 and the only one close to $100 to sell will be virtually unsed in mint condition with a wide selection of accessories, bag, batteries, chargers, ect.

threads.com:
Crushed dreams and lost hope Edition
All video related questions and discussion is intended for this thread. Here we discuss techniques, gear and anything else related to capturing video footage. Please don't pretend to be an expert if you don't know what you're talking about. Kindly leave your ego at the door.
Posting short films/scripts or other work you've done is encouraged.
We tend to use and recommend DSLRs/mirrorless cameras because they provide phenomenal picture quality for their price, have large sensors (ie the same size used in high-end cinema cameras and higher) and have interchangeable lenses.
In contrast, consumer camcorders normally have much smaller sensors and a fixed lens.

>STICKY -https://textbin.net/2u146abxla
>Helpful guide, additional books and more in-depth FAQs - https://web.archive.org/web/20200926115310/https://pastebin.com/kG0gRmTZ

>NO ONE CARES WHAT AN EXPERT YOU THINK YOU ARE. IF YOU’RE ASKING BASIC-AS-SHIT QUESTIONS, YOU CAN’T BE ALL THAT GREAT. SEE ABOVE

Previous thread >>4095075

Quick FAQS
>what’s the best camera available on a “budget”?
The blackmagic pocket cinema camera 4k
>>what’s a good beginner video camera?
Anything that works, shoots at least 1080p and preferably has interchangeable lenses. Any recommendation beyond that will cause arguments so read the fucking sticky if that isn't satisfactory.
>Can I use a zoom lens for video?
Yes
>Do I need cine lenses?
No
>Do I need 4k?
No. It will make your footage look sharper if it’s in focus, and it gives you breathing room in post. But 1080p is still absolutely fine
>Can someone tell me if my video is any good?
Yes, but be prepared to receive harsh criticism. If you're going to waste 5 minutes of our time with a shitty out-of-focus montage of nothing then we'll tell you that it's crap

You will be more likely to be hired as an assistant photographer if you have a full frame camera with at least 36mp, the two essential pro zooms (24-70 f2.8 and 70-200 f2.8) and a dedicated flash head. A portrait-oriented prime lens with an aperture of f1.7 or faster and a focal length of 50 to 100mm can be a decent addition. For sports you want even more zoom but I've only ever seen job openings for assistant event photographers

You will also need a portfolio of photos of the kind of thing you are trying to get a job photographing. This proves you know how to use a camera and won't shoot an entire wedding at f2.8, 1/8s, ISO 400.

last_replies.name: Art_repro_fag22
last_replies.com:
>>4099851
The only benefit of CCD based camera sensors is that they're cheap. SNR is worse, color accuracy is worse, no live view, and slower sensor read-out. There are other drawbacks that aren't due to the sensor tech, but rather due to the age of the rest of the camera. Worse burst rates, slower AF, etc.
>>4100265
CCD and CMOS due have very different spectral response without a CFA. This is why most scientific applications have CCDs. https://www.researchgate.net/figure/3-Spectral-sensitivity-graph-of-CCD-sensor-CMOS-sensor-and-human-eye-3-Width-is-5mm_fig3_216533561
>>4100533
While color accuracy has gone up with recent CFA design, its not due to less noise, its due to wider response of the filters. Though less noise is benefit of this design choice.
https://blog.kasson.com/the-last-word/optimal-cfa-spectral-response/
>>4100492
CCD's thick CFA's color response is no closer to slide film than modern CFA response. It was the camera input profiles that gave that look. Even if your goal is crazy color, its better to start with accurate color then go from there.
>>4100543
This is not true. Old MF CCDs have massive 9 micron pixels and yet still has worse SNR than any modern baby sensor. Camera processing is much harder with old CCDs due to noise and inaccurate color.
>>4103713
Filter correlation with sRGB primaries, or any other working color space doesn't tell you much about color accuracy. This is because camera sensors are linear, and working spaces have gamma. Brightness of colors relative to each(color and brightness contrast) is by far the most important aspect of color accuracy, which is initially determined by the camera input profile.
We also don't want our filters to line up with a working space in the first place, we want our camera to see colors like we do, aka the CIEXYZ color space. This is because working spaces have a defined white point, usually D50. the standard observer accounts for human color perception under any lighting conditions.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>4105113
>We also don't want our filters to line up with a working space in the first place, we want our camera to see colors like we do, aka the CIEXYZ color space. This is because working spaces have a defined white point, usually D50. the standard observer accounts for human color perception under any lighting conditions.
Look at the picture again. It's precisely what SMI is about. CIE-D50 is the standard they're using in that test.

last_replies.name: Art_repro_fag22
last_replies.com:
>>4105203
You and dxomark are both confused and mistaken. SMI is pretty complex measurement using the CC24 target under a well defined Standard illuminant, usually A(Tungsten) or D50. Its a measure of how close the camera filter primaries are to CIEXYZ observer primaries. If SMI is 100, a linear transformation can get you perfect color. While they do include CMI, they're all similar to each other.
>Look at the picture again. It's precisely what SMI is about. CIE-D50 is the standard they're using in that test.
If you read into the testing methodology, they test CMI, but don't use it in their score. They instead use correlation with sRGB primaries, which doesn't mean anything. CIE-D50 is a Standard illuminant, and has very little to do with CIEXYZ, which is light source independent.
SMI honestly isnt a very good color accuracy metric anyways. In color critical work, you will usually be using some kind of LUT based profile instead of matrix profile. SMI only tells us how well a camera will respond to a matrix based profile under ideal lighting conditions for a small(and not that difficult to reproduce) set of colors.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>4105669
>iso
ISO is essentially telling your camera how much to boost the brightness of the photo you just took.
Manually controlling your ISO setting can have some workflow benefits, but is usually not necessary.
Set up your camera to automatically set an appropriate ISO, with the low ISO limit being your camera's "base" ISO, usually 100.
Usually, your camera will choose an ISO settings to that the image averages out to a "middle grey".
This is helpful in adequate lighting, but the scene you're photographing is "dark", not "average".
So control your camera's automatic ISO by dialing exposure compensation down. This is usually measured in "stops", with lowering one stop meaning the scene is half as bright.
The meter display along the bottom of your viewfinder will indicate the exposure. The large pips are full stops, with the small pips usually representing each third of a stop.
For this photo, dial exposure compensation down until you see the meter shows your photo will be very "underexposed" - meaning "very much darker than average".

last_replies.com:
>>4105670
Predicting how a photo will turn out is a skill that comes with practice.
Photography will become much easier and faster for you once you can pre-visualize your desired image, and instinctively know what settings would be necessary.

The intrepid 8x10 is also complete garbage, you'll likely waste thousands in film trying to chase down light leaks and dealing with a front standard so flimsy that it can't actually hold any 8x10 lenses in place.

Found the box of prairie images I shot on the way up to Alaska. Still have to develop the rest of the box and then I'm all done with development. Here's one shot on the way up, a grain elevator glowing in the mixed light of twilight and the red sign from a bar/liquor store across the street in a long 10 minute exposure.

Yes it's another gear thread, sorry guys. But you'll tell it to me like it is with no hype or shilling.

So I'm looking into buying into a full frame mirrorless system. I shoot seriously, but not professionally (I don't depend on it for my main income). I'm looking at used cameras in the 'enthusiast / low end professional' spectrum, so basically SontyA7(R/S)ii/iii, Nikon Z6i/ii, Canon EOS R. I'm hoping to get a used camera, and one or two decent primes for around 2000 USD.

I shoot mainly event photography at 'alternative events', very frequently wth poor or moody lighting, so low light performance and noise quality is important to me. I am a huge raw processing / color calibration geek, so I basically don't care at all about how images look SOOC.

Yes, I know that it's the photographer and not the gear and all that, but also I'm looking at spending quite a bit of money and buying into an ecosystem here so I'd like to consider my options carefully.

So are there any clear winners here, or clear losers to avoid?

These telescoping tripods aren't usable for heavy cameras. I have a prinz one with steel legs and it's clearly unstable and leaning/bending with a light film SLR and anything heavier than a short prime. You would want a general tripod collar for anything more front heavy. With the legs collapsed, they make good tabletop mounts for small spotting scopes, and are usable for very light and well balanced camera setups but nothing bigger. I keep mine in my range bag and use it to hold up phones for phonetography if those are the cameras that are available.

threads.com:
Halloween Edition
All video related questions and discussion is intended for this thread. Here we discuss techniques, gear and anything else related to capturing video footage. Please don't pretend to be an expert if you don't know what you're talking about. Kindly leave your ego at the door.
Posting short films/scripts or other work you've done is encouraged.
We tend to use and recommend DSLRs/mirrorless cameras because they provide phenomenal picture quality for their price, have large sensors (ie the same size used in high-end cinema cameras and higher) and have interchangeable lenses.
In contrast, consumer camcorders normally have much smaller sensors and a fixed lens.

>STICKY -https://textbin.net/2u146abxla
>Helpful guide, additional books and more in-depth FAQs - https://web.archive.org/web/20200926115310/https://pastebin.com/kG0gRmTZ

>NO ONE CARES WHAT AN EXPERT YOU THINK YOU ARE. IF YOU’RE ASKING BASIC-AS-SHIT QUESTIONS, YOU CAN’T BE ALL THAT GREAT. SEE ABOVE

Previous thread >>4085831

Quick FAQS
>what’s the best camera available on a “budget”?
The blackmagic pocket cinema camera 4k
>>what’s a good beginner video camera?
Anything that works, shoots at least 1080p and preferably has interchangeable lenses. Any recommendation beyond that will cause arguments so read the fucking sticky if that isn't satisfactory.
>Can I use a zoom lens for video?
Yes
>Do I need cine lenses?
No
>Do I need 4k?
No. It will make your footage look sharper if it’s in focus, and it gives you breathing room in post. But 1080p is still absolutely fine
>Can someone tell me if my video is any good?
Yes, but be prepared to receive harsh criticism. If you're going to waste 5 minutes of our time with a shitty out-of-focus montage of nothing then we'll tell you that it's crap

Of course. Cameras are just tools. Each one is different. Some more than others.

I started with Yashica TLRs. They are relatively inexpensive and have good lenses. I still use them as a backup because they are light and small. I do a lot of backpacking and enjoy the weight aspect.

I then started using a Kiev 60. The lenses are cheap and decent. The cameras are finicky and very heavy. Depending on the camera you might have to mess with it to get it running. I saved up and bought a Hassy 500cm body and a Distagon 50mm. Have not received the lens yet. They are insanely expensive and I paid out the ass for an extra clean one. threads.name: Anonymous
threads.com:
Talk about something you get autistic over in photography.
I'll start.

I've followed this advice since the start of time, if I am to shoot handheld and there's not enough light, and my camera has let's say a 50mm lens on. My lowest acceptable shutter speed should be 1/50s. In practice if I hold very very steady I can maybe go to 1/30s and still get an acceptable image.
Now. If on crop sensors, because of the crop factor, a 33mm lens is equivalent to a 50mm while letting me shoot with a 1/30s all the while getting a good image would mean technically that it is better at low light photography, excluding noise and desired photo characteristics.
But... Larger sensors have less noise, which sort of balances the need for a theoretically higher acceptable shutter speed. But to what extent?
Also, if a camera has sensor stabilization, how far can I push my acceptable shutter speed below the normal acceptable speed? 1 stop? 2 stops?
Looking at the tiny amount of data regarding this online (maybe because most photographers are not this autistic), I'm starting to think that a newer, less noisy, image stabilized APS-C camera might reign supreme in terms of low light handheld shooting.

threads.com:
Okay if light is traveling all over the place and it is clear and colored, why doesn't it look as trippy as pic related?

[EXIF data available. Click here to show/hide.]
Camera-Specific Properties:
Image-Specific Properties:
Image OrientationUnknown

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>4103113
>>4103115
anon is correct. the lens in your eye ball focuses light to the retina (although it struggles with higher wavelengths so blue and violet are never actually in focus but it's close enough for your brain to cope and compensate).

when light is traveling through air it's generally all wavelengths which we are not particularly sensitive to in terms of colour, only as luminance. when it strikes an object of a certain colour or pigment it means that object absorbs all the wavelengths that aren't the colour but reflects wavelenghts that are that colour. your pupil is narrow enough that scattered reflections don't get to your retina, only the reflections that are arriving more directly to the pupil, further focused by the lens in your eye. this is why peripheral vision is always out of focus even if you try to draw your attention to it, and also why technically your eye is only ever focused on a single pinpoint but your visual system is quite adept at making you feel as though you are grasping the whole scene in front of you, largely through central nervous system processing and constant micro glances to scan the scene in front of you.

fun fax: the very center of our vision has very slow response to movement and sees absolutely nothing but color (i.e. no contrast at all) but it is the only part of our vision that is actually in focus. the periphery of our vision is extremely sensitive to movement and is biased toward contrast and sees very little color. in reality our vision is incredibly weak and dull in relationship to many of our animal cousins.

during scotopic vision (when your eyes are adjusted to seeing in low light) you are completely blind to whatever you look directly at. if you want to have a look at something, you have to glance away slightly and it'll appear in your peripheral vision, and never in focus. the extreme sensitivity to movement that we experience in our peripheral vision is what kept us from getting ate by the dinosaurs.

try making a pinhole camera someday. your pupils are small enough so that only light arriving at narrrow angles reaches the focal point of the retina. that alone keeps objects in focus, scattered random light does not reach your retinas, only the light coming from objects you're looking at reaches the retina.

threads.sub: I bought a Canon R10 - Did I make a mistake?
threads.com:
So 5-6 years ago I purchased a Canon 6D with a "nifty fifty" as well as a 35mm Sigma Art f/1.4 lens. It cost me about $2000, which was a lot of money for me at the time (especially since I'm only a hobby photographer).

Anyway, I wanted to upgrade to a mirrorless camera due to its better autofocusing system etc, so after a lot of reading (I was mostly researching full frame cameras), I ended up ordering an APS-C camera (the Canon R10).

My thinking was, due to the 1.6x crop factor, my 50mm would become an 80mm lens and my 35mm Sigma would become 56mm. And I wanted a lens in this region for portrait photography.

But now I hear that just attaching one of these full frame lenses via an EF to RF mount, could actually make the IQ worse.

Did I make a mistake buying a cropped sensor camera? Especially since I mostly do portrait photography nowadays? Should I have just sold everything I had and started fresh with a full-frame Sony or Nikon?

Sensor size isn’t a meme if you compare over larger distances, like MFT to FF. When you push them to the extremes of shitty light and high dynamic range in one exposure it gets obvious even APSC to FF but night photographers are a minority and many of them appreciate a compressed lofi look.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
Use an old film lens (the rendering style, color cast, and softness are part of the look)
Use a glimmerglass filter (softens highlights... and detail)
Totally kill color noise at the cost of sharpness, leave luminance noise, maybe even increase it.
Shoot in soft natural lighting or git gud. Artificial light, especially flash, was difficult for most people to use for the longest time, so most film shots are either in very good light or ambient light.
Use a fixed white balance. Use a fixed ISO instead of coping and using it and EV values to fix exposures. This is a stylistic choice but the result is film-y thematic consistency shot to shot.

If it's close or above freezing do whatever you do when shooting in rain. I'd bring a tough.
If its well under freezing, any camera from most major brands should be fine. (Is Snoy and water still a meme?) Just bring spare batteries and shoot away. When entering indoors, remove any loose snow and put the camera in dry place to warm.
Remember: Warranty does not cover water damage.

last_replies.com: Pat it dry, snow shouldn't be a problem, water is. Wiping tends to drive the water deeper inside your camera.

editing general thread
editing is arguably the most important aspect of photography. no matter how interesting your subject, composition, and the overall context of your work is, it must have striking contrast, colors, and other things. In most cases, editing is where your personal style is most clearly defined. Do you go for low saturated earth tones and intentional underexposure? Do you go for pastel colors with high luminance? very saturated primary colors? low contrast b&w? cinematic color grading? What's your style and how do you achieve it
